skill.name: connecting-to-logseq
skill.description: Manages connections to Logseq graphs via HTTP API, CLI, or MCP Server. Auto-invokes when users mention connecting to Logseq, API tokens, graph paths, connection issues, or backend configuration. Handles backend detection, environment setup, and connectivity troubleshooting.

security_audit.summary: This skill is a legitimate Logseq API client for knowledge graph integration. All network calls go to localhost only (127.0.0.1:12315). Tokens are handled via environment variables using security best practices. Static findings are false positives triggered by documentation examples showing standard API client patterns and Datalog query syntax.

evidence.description: HTTP API endpoint at http://127.0.0.1:12315 - localhost only
All API endpoints point to localhost Logseq instance
Security notes confirm API only listens on localhost
Token stored in LOGSEQ_API_TOKEN environment variable
Config uses ${LOGSEQ_API_TOKEN} syntax for env var substitution
Documentation examples for CLI commands - not runtime execution
cURL examples for API testing - documentation only

content.value_statement: Users need to integrate Claude with their Logseq knowledge graphs for querying and writing data. This skill provides automated connection management across HTTP API, CLI, and MCP Server backends with built-in troubleshooting support.
actual_capabilities: Auto-detect available Logseq backends (HTTP API, CLI, MCP)
Configure and validate Logseq API connections with token authentication
Set up environment variables and configuration files securely
Troubleshoot connection issues and authentication errors
Execute Datalog queries against Logseq graphs
Manage graph paths and backend selection automatically
limitations: Requires Logseq to be running for HTTP API and MCP backends
CLI backend has limited write capabilities compared to HTTP API
Cannot connect to remote Logseq instances over the internet
Does not create or manage Logseq graphs directly

best_practices: Store your Logseq API token in environment variables, never in config files or scripts
Always verify your Logseq HTTP API is enabled before attempting connections
Use absolute paths for graph directories to avoid relative path issues in automation
Restart Logseq after changing API settings to ensure changes take effect
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API tokens in configuration files or commit messages
Using relative paths for graph directories in automated workflows
Attempting connections without verifying Logseq is running
Sharing Logseq API tokens in chat messages, commits, or public forums

faq.question: What backends does this skill support?
faq.answer: HTTP API (requires running Logseq), CLI (offline support with limited writes), and MCP Server (Claude-native tools).

faq.question: Does the skill work with remote Logseq instances?
faq.answer: No. The Logseq HTTP API only listens on localhost. All connections stay on your local machine.

faq.question: What permissions does this skill need?
faq.answer: Read, Write, Edit for configuration files. Bash, Grep, Glob for script execution and environment detection.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. All API calls stay on localhost. Tokens are handled via environment variables, never stored in plain text.

faq.question: Why am I getting connection refused errors?
faq.answer: Common causes: Logseq not running, HTTP API not enabled, wrong port (default 12315), or firewall blocking localhost.

faq.question: How is this different from other data skills?
faq.answer: This skill is specialized for Logseq's unique architecture including Datalog queries, datascript schema, and graph-based storage.
